Hey all. I just finished posting the first beta of Rawr v2.2:

http://rawr.codeplex.com/Release/ProjectReleases.aspx?ReleaseId=25093

It's not done yet, but we wanted to show everyone what we're working on, since it makes such a big difference. It's beta quality; you'll probably encounter some bugs. Please use this thread to report bugs and give feedback on the new gemming system. Thanks!

EDIT: Replaced link with v2.2.0b5.

FYI, there was a crashing bug in Rawr.Enhance, and a bug with gemming templates for Enhance and ProtWarr being all disabled by default. I fixed those, and reposted v2.2.0b1. The version number hasn't changed, but if you are one of the 90 people who downloaded it before 8:20 PST, and use either of those two models, re-download v2.2.0b1.

It is still unintuitive and only marginally better than the previous incarnation (for me), as far as I can tell in the time I've had to play with it so far.

It boils down to the fact that I still don't "get" the idea of templates. Why not just have:

Select the gems you want us to consider. We'll figure out the best combination to fill your sockets.

Red: Runed Scarlet Ruby
Yellow: Quick Autumn's Glow
Blue:
Green: Forceful Forest Emerald
Orange: Reckless Monarch Topaz, Potent Monarch Topaz
Purple: Glowing Twilight Opal
Meta: Chaotic Skyflare Diamond

And have optimizer figure it out from there. There must be something about the benefit of templates that I'm missing. In any case, here's my initial feedback.

Edit: Apparently gemming templates are only used for the comparison chart and have no affect on optimizer (aside from the option mentioned below).

I don't think it should, buying a bs socket doesn't put a gem in it, and potentially there are several options what you want to put in it. You also don't have to switch back and forth with another item. When you tick bs socket the comparison chart will list all gemmings that utilize the bs socket, in addition it will show the current item without the gem in the socket. All you have to do is equip whichever version of the item you want, no need for two equips.

korey:

The main reason why we don't try to determine the best gemming out of all possible combinations is because of performance reasons. It is just not feasible to do that for comparison charts. Besides optimizer already does that.

Another thing to note is that the best possible gemming it shows based on templates is most likely the best overall, so maybe the only thing you're missing is the option to hide all except top n gemmings of an item. That is still planned before we put a final release out as noted in the the help section, we just didn't have time to put it in this beta preview.

Kavan: Ohhh. Is the only point of the templates for the comparison charts on the right? If so, then I take my above post back, although it may be good to explain to users what the point of the gemming system is. Optimizer only looks at the available gems you have checked off and has nothing to do with the gemming system?

If I uncheck all of the 'templates' in the gemming templates, but select the gems i like in the comparison charts with the diamond, and run the optimizer, will the optimizer just choose all of the best gemmings regardless of what I chose in templates?  I don't think this is how it works (although this is how korey is misinterpreting your statements, as far as I can tell), because otherwise how would it know when, or when not to use Jewelcrafting gems.

The gemming system and the optimizer are entirely separate, with only one exception: There is an option (which is ON by default), to count all gems in enabled gemming templates as available to the optimizer. The optimizer will still take all of those gems and find the best possible gemmings for all your gear. That's in Tools > Options > Optimizer Options.

The gemming templates are used only for creating gemmings of items for comparisons in the charts. 


Also, that reminds me, I forgot to mention. Another feature to the gemming system that is still coming is that the "Enforce Metagem Requirements" checkbox will soon become "Enforce Gem Requirements*" On hover, it'll say, "When checked, gems will not be counted towards your stats, if you do not meet their requirements. This includes metagems where you don't meet the metagem requirement, and unique gems where you already have the maximum number of those gems (such as Dragon Eyes, and Enchanted Tears)".

Yes gemming templates are only used for comparison charts. The main point of gemming templates is that before item cache stored each gemming of an item and as result you'd end up with agi gems in cloth gear and similar. With the new system the item cache only stores the item information, gemmings are created as needed based on what model you are using.

Optimizer as before only uses whatever gems are marked as available. There is a new option though (enabled by default) to treat gems from enabled templates as enabled for optimizer. This is mainly to make it easier for new users so they can load a character from armory and go straight to optimize without having to mark everything as available. The same as before optimizer looks at all possible combinations of available gems, it is not restricted to combinations available in templates.

If you have jewelcrafting gems marked as available the optimizer checks how many total jewelcrafting gems are equipped and if there are more than 3 it marks that gear set as 0 score. This is not done for comparison charts although we might add another option to enforce jewelcrafting gem count similar to how we have enforce meta gem.

Regarding optimizing several sets at a time. You can do this kindof with the batch tools. The reason why I say kind of is because you can't do it in one pass. Check the help page on batch tools, I described there the way I'm using it for multiset optimizations. Basically I'm using the batch upgrade list for multi-set gemming/enchant suggestions and then use batch optimizer on the fixed gemming/enchants to optimize each set.

One day I'll probably decide to make the batch optimizer what it should be and optimize cross-set and not just per-set. Basically doing an optimization over selecting gemming/enchants per item and using the weighted per-set optimizer as the valuation for it. Just writing it down makes me squirm from thinking about how slow it would be. If either of you would like to collaborate on this let me know.
